xxl.cursors
Class AbstractCursor

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.cursors.AbstractCursor
Direct Known Subclasses:
DivideAndConquer, Divider, InputIterator, RandomIntegers, RandomRectangle, Sampler, SingleObjectCursor
public abstract class AbstractCursor
extends Object
implements Cursor

The AbstractCursor implements most of the methods of the Cursor-interface and is useful in those cases when you produce elements and want to ³return³ them by a Cursor. For example consider a query-operation on an index structure that returns an Iterator of results.
It is sufficient then to create an AbstractCursor and implement the abstract method computeNext().
computeNext() is a protected method that is only called internally by the AbstractCursor whenever a new result is requested on that Cursor. The contract of computeNext() is that it computes the next element (hence its name).



Example usage: The RandomIntegers-Cursor produces a certain number (noOfObjects) of random Integer-Objects by calling Random.nextInt(). RandomIntegers extends AbstractCursor and the implementation of computeNext() is as follows: 


 	protected void computeNext(){
 		if(noOfObjects-- > 0)
 			setNext(new Integer(random.nextInt(maxValue)));
 }
This means, as long as noOfObjects > 0 holds the next result of the AbstractCursor will be set to: 
 	new Integer(random.nextInt(maxValue));
The protected method setNext(Object object) sets the next object to be returned by this AbstractCursor. If noOfObjects <= 0 holds no result will be set, i.e. all consequent calls to hasNext() will return false.

If you want to pass an entire Iterator in computeNext() to the AbstractCursor you should call 

 	boolean setNextIterator(Iterator iterator);
where ³iterator³ is an Iterator that must not be empty. In that case, the elements contained in the iterator will be returned by this Cursor and computeNext() will only be called again when the iterator is empty. (The method returns false, if myIterator was empty.)

See Also:
RandomIntegers, Iterator, Cursor

protected abstract  void computeNext()
          Computes the next element (Contract: this method computes the next element to be returned by a call to next(), it sets the next-field by calling setNext(Object), or setNextIterator(Iterator), this method is only called by getNext()).
 boolean hasNext()
          Returns true if the iteration has more elements.
(In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
If the field hasNext is true, this method also returns true, otherwise it calls getNext and then returns the value of the field hasNext.
 Object next()
          Returns the next element in the iteration.
This element will be removed from the underlying collection, if next is called.
 Object peek()
          Shows the next element in the iteration without removing it from the underlying collection.
 void remove()
          Removes from the underlying collection the last element returned by the AbstractCursor.
 void reset()
          Resets the AbstractCursor to its initial state.
So the caller is able to traverse the underlying collection again.

(IMPORTANT: This method is called setNextIterator and not setNext because this is a potential source of bugs if this AbstractCursor is a Cursors of Iterators.

Constructor Detail

AbstractCursor

public AbstractCursor()
Method Detail

close

public void close()
Closes the AbstractCursor. Signals the AbstractCursor to cleanup resources, close files, etc.
After a call to close() calls to methods like next() or peek() are not guarantied to yield proper results.
Multiple calls to close() do not have any effect, i.e. if close() was called the AbstractCursor remains in the state "closed".
Specified by:
close in interface Cursor

hasNext

public boolean hasNext()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements.
(In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
If the field hasNext is true, this method also returns true, otherwise it calls getNext and then returns the value of the field hasNext.
Specified by:
hasNext in interface Cursor
Returns:
true if the AbstractCursor has more elements.

computeNext

protected abstract void computeNext()
Computes the next element (Contract: this method computes the next element to be returned by a call to next(), it sets the next-field by calling setNext(Object), or setNextIterator(Iterator), this method is only called by getNext()).

setNext

protected void setNext(Object next)
Sets the attribute next and sets hasNext = true.
Parameters:
next - the next object that should be returned by this AbstractCursor.

setNextIterator

protected boolean setNextIterator(Iterator iterator)
Sets the attribute next with the given non-empty Iterator and sets hasNext = true.
(IMPORTANT: This method is called setNextIterator and not setNext because this is a potential source of bugs if this AbstractCursor is a Cursors of Iterators. In that case it would not be clear which method has to be called).
Parameters:
iterator - the Iterator to be passed by the AbstractCursor.
Returns:
false if the Iterator is empty, true otherwise.

next

public Object next()
            throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the iteration.
This element will be removed from the underlying collection, if next is called. If hasNext is false getNext() will be called, otherwise hasNext is set to false and next is returned.
Specified by:
next in interface Cursor
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if the iteration has no more elements.

peek

public Object peek()
            throws NoSuchElementException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Shows the next element in the iteration without removing it from the underlying collection. (optional operation)
Specified by:
peek in interface Cursor
Returns:
the next element in the iteration
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - iteration has no more elements.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the peek operation is not supported by this AbstractCursor.

remove

public void remove()
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Removes from the underlying collection the last element returned by the AbstractCursor. (optional operation)
This method can be called only once per call to next or peek. The behavior of an AbstractCursor is unspecified if the underlying collection is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.
Specified by:
remove in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by this AbstractCursor.
IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the remove method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.

reset

public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the AbstractCursor to its initial state.
So the caller is able to traverse the underlying collection again. The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying collection, are still persistent. (optional operation)
Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset method is not supported by the AbstractCursor.

supportsPeek

public boolean supportsPeek()
Returns true if the peek-operation is supported by this AbstractCursor. Else returns false.
Specified by:
supportsPeek in interface Cursor
Returns:
true if the peek operation is supported by this AbstractCursor.

update

public void update(Object object)
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
This method is not supported by AbstractCursors. If this method is called an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown. (optional operation)
Specified by:
update in interface Cursor
Parameters:
object - the object that replaces the object returned by the last call to next or peek.
Throws:
IllegalStateException - if there is no object which can be updated.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the update operation is not supported by the AbstractCursor.
